metadata.case_name: Petitioner v. Union of India (Ministry of Defence)

facts.text: Temporary Clerks recruited in Defence Establishment of Army Ordnance Corps from as early as 1925 against sanctioned posts, central control, records at Jubbalpore (later Secunderabad).

In 1933, need for larger establishment led to recruitment under Financial Regulations of India (FRI) Part I Para 25, known as Extra Temporary Establishment (ETE), records unit-wise, technically discharged annually on 31st March if sanctioned more than six months.
Petitioner employed by Ministry of Defence, Army Ordnance Corps as Extra Temporary Establishment Clerk on February 6, 1942.

Government of India dispatch dated August 6, 1941 permitted recruitment of ETE Clerks on monthly rates (Grades A, B, C) instead of daily wages for war period, debited to ETE budget, one month's notice, no transfer except on request, no overtime.
Order dated July 25, 1942 clarified maintenance of ETE Clerks on daily or monthly rates, improved monthly wages for Grade A to Rs. 85/- minimum.

Towards end of WWII, Army Instructions India No. 676 of 1945 (effective September 1, 1944) unified Temporary Clerks into Grades A, B, C, liability for service anywhere, unified pay scales, house rent allowance, option within three months retrospective from September 1, 1944.

Army Instructions India 458 of 1946 gave ETE Clerks option to elect Army Instructions 676 of 1945 terms if suitable and minimum service since September 1, 1944, previous continuous service counted for promotion, other terms as per 676 of 1945, effective from September 1, 1944 or later.
Petitioner and large number of ETE Clerks opted for revised rules under Army Instructions 458 of 1946, accepted by competent authorities.
Order dated August 14, 1946 decided interim measure: amalgamate interim establishment and ETE vacancies for unit promotion, cease All India Rule temporarily, affiliate small units to larger depots.
On February 3, 1947, ETE personnel opting for unified scales still required annual technical discharge under FRI Rule 25, not affecting agreements.
Order dated February 15, 1947 cancelled August 14, 1946 order, decided no amalgamation of ETE and ISP rolls following BIOAC conference.

Government of India order dated August 19, 1949 abolished Temporary Establishment and ETE designations, classified into non-industrial and industrial, non-industrial (clerical) brought to regular establishment from August 1, 1949, entitled to CSR benefits, treated as whole-time regular Government servants.
Ministry of Defence communication dated January 4, 1950 clarified: where possible, merge into one cadre, ETE seniority from August 1, 1949 vis-a-vis IPE; else keep separate.
Formal order CPRO 513 of 1951 dated June 7, 1951 issued per January 4, 1950 clarification.

Representations by ex-ETE to reconsider seniority, leading to order dated April 20, 1955: in modification, half of continuous ETE service prior to August 1, 1949 in concerned/equivalent grades to count for seniority in amalgamated roster.
Impugned order resulted in 610 Clerks from former Temporary Establishment gaining seniority over petitioner.
Nearly 6,000 ETE personnel affected if order set aside; 600-1000 adversely affected if set aside, interveners on both sides.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order dated April 20, 1955 modifying seniority computation by counting only half pre-August 1, 1949 ETE service for ex-ETE Clerks vis-a-vis Temporary Clerks is unconstitutional under Articles 14 and 16(1) as discriminatory.
Whether the two services (Temporary Establishment and ETE) were integrated/unified prior to the impugned order, entitling ex-ETE Clerks to full length of service for seniority.

petitioner_arguments.text: ETE and Temporary Clerks had same qualifications grade-for-grade, same duties, substantially similar service conditions; impugned order discriminates by counting only half pre-1949 ETE service for seniority, allowing juniors from Temporary to supersede.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 14, 16(1); General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari

petitioner_arguments.text: Unification occurred via Army Instructions 676/1945, 458/1946, August 14, 1946 communication, and August 19, 1949 order; common roll with seniority by date of entry into service.
February 15, 1947 cancellation arbitrary, under pressure, no principle; January 4, 1950 clarification and June 7, 1951 CPRO departed from 1949 policy.

respondent_arguments.text: No integration of services; Temporary and ETE remained distinct; August 14, 1946 order cancelled by February 15, 1947; ETE joined regular establishment only from August 1, 1949.
Impugned 1955 order confers concession by counting half pre-1949 service, improving position over 1949/1950/1951 orders.

court_reasoning.text: Two services had different origins, recruitment bases, conditions; unification attempts failed, August 14, 1946 cancelled February 15, 1947; remained parallel despite similarities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No common seniority roll pre-1949; ETE entered regular/IPE only from August 1, 1949.

court_reasoning.text: August 19, 1949 order did not specify inter se seniority; natural result from history: ETE seniority from August 1, 1949; January 4, 1950 clarification part of 1949 order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: CPRO 1951 formalised existing position, no change post-Constitution.

court_reasoning.text: No vested right to full pre-1949 service for seniority on Constitution date; 1955 order improves position, not discriminates.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No violation of Arts. 14 or 16(1); petition lacks factual basis.

holdings.text: Services not unified pre-Constitution; ETE seniority from August 1, 1949; 1955 order valid, confers benefit.
No discrimination under Art. 14 or inequality under Art. 16(1); impugned order constitutional.

precedents_cited.case_name: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 16(1) covers equality in service including promotions, not just initial recruitment.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Guarantees equal protection, equality of opportunity in public employment; basis for writ petition.

statutes_cited.name: Financial Regulations of India (FRI)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governed ETE recruitment, annual technical discharge.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Service Regulations, Civilians in Defence Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Benefits for regularised non-industrial staff from August 1, 1949.

outcome.summary: Writ petition under Art. 32 challenging April 20, 1955 order as violative of Arts. 14 and 16(1) dismissed; no unification of services, no discrimination, order beneficial. Special Leave Petition No. 786 of 1961 also dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The impugned order, therefore, far from adversely affecting the petitioner, really conferred upon him larger rights than he previously possessed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of holding that 1955 order benefits petitioner, no violation.

key_quotes.text: The two Services remained separate and were not amalgamated into a unified Service.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects petitioner's claim of pre-existing integration.

key_quotes.text: Art. 16(1) guaranteed not merely an equality in regard to initial employment i.e., recruitment but also ensured that there shall be equality throughout the length of the service including the right to promotions.
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
